lg.l: Along the stream Stream. The Ohio Creek in the Coromandel ranges, near Thames, in the North Island of New Zealand. we took our way,
Where hidden deep in shadow lay
The graceful nikau Nikau. The nikau, New Zealand’s only native palm, is found in the North Island and as far south as the Canterbury region in the South Island. and the fern,
Their branches reaching o’er the burn.
Traces of recent storm and flood,
In bridges broken, holes of mud,
Are noticed; and the traveller finds,
Crossings of strange artistic kinds.
Ceaseless for ages has this brook
Ran rippling on, round curve and crook;
Cutting away, by gentle shock,
Its devious path thro’ hardest rock.
Perchance in the far distant past,
Some Maori warrior’s home was cast
Amid these hill[s], and on this shore
Found his supply of fern roots store.
Half hidden from the Sun’s fierce heat
Is many a cool moss-covered seat,
Where weary tourists Tourists. At the time, tourists visited the area of the Ohio Creek to view a giant kauri tree. for a while
May rest, in most luxurious style;
And contemplate the scenery round,
Tree, rock, and hill, with fern-clad ground.
Pleasant it is at such a time,
Attentive listening to the rhyme
Of Nature’s music all around;
The whispering breeze, and brook’s low sound,
Where flowing o’er its pebbly bed,
While birds are warbling overhead.
Like rift in cloud on Winter’s day
Gleam thro’ the trees the Sun’s bright ray,
Casting on brook a burnished sheen,
And tinting leaves with various green.
Dreamily pass the hours while thus,
Far from the world’s turmoil and fuss,
We drink in beauty, nor regret
That we with solitude have met.
Health gains improvement, and the life
More vigorous grows more fit for strife,
By sometimes stopping in the race,
And letting youth her step retrace.
Awhile forgetting busy care,
The workshop desk, the office stair,
And school-room close confinement leave,
Glad to escape, pure air to breathe.
And should the thoughts in fancy stray
To other scenes now far away,
To earlier days of life gone by,
And other forms that low now lie.
Still such remembrance shall not check
Our day’s enjoyment, for there yet
Remains the fact, that over all
The course of life, its rise and fall,
God rules supreme; this thought shall cheer
Our days, while still continuing here;
Guiding with tenderest love our way,
Though oft forgetful we may stray.
Thoughts now arise that here perchance
Lies hidden treasure, Hidden treasure. The Coromandel gold rush began in 1867. which the advance
Of science shall unearth, and then
Will busy [crowds] explore this glen,
Of wealth oft searched for here before.
And changing Nature’s beauteous face
In one of profit, not of grace.
Here at the hardy miner’s word,
May stampers[‘] Stampers. Stamper batteries were machines used to extract gold from quartz. music yet be heard,
And cottage neat, with garden ground,
Be seen on many a rising mound.
Such be the future, but to-day
The hills in freshest verdure lay,
Unsullied by the hand of man,
And tree clad far as eye can scan.
But now wild fancy draw thy rein,
Nor needlessly prolong the strain
Of melancholy musing.
